Award.AwardTitle: SDCI Net: Phoebus: An Integrated System for End-to-end High Performance Networking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
End-to-end high performance networking must continue to develop to keep pace with the computing ecosystem. While the community continues to make significant strides in high-performance computing, the ability to transfer the vast amounts of data generated by scientists has failed to increase commensurately. When scientists spend time dealing with data movement, or are limited by lack of timely access to data, the potential for scientific progress is hampered. Today, there are many application communities struggling with the well-known performance problems in TCP/IP in order to do the real work they need to do.
This proposal would support the continued development and deployment of Phoebus, a protocol and service implementation for improving end-to-end transfers to gigabit speeds. Phoebus provides a network "inlay" that augments the network topology with an additional layer of protocol and functionality. Phoebus leverages the ubiquitous TCP/IPv4 implementation on the end hosts, while providing an adaptor to translate to a variety of alternate protocols over the wide area, including creation of virtual networks on the fly. Many data-intensive applications can use Phoebus without modification and without making any system-level changes.
Phoebus makes use of a session-layer protocol called XSP, for eXtensible Session Protocol, for end-to-end communication and uses various transport layer protocol instances on different segments of the network, as appropriate. In many cases, performance can be improved by simply using existing protocols tuned based on network conditions and properties. Similarly, a high performance TCP alternative can be used when more assumptions about the underlying network can be made.

Phoebus is essentially a WAN accelerator for research and education networks. This project will work with various application communities to modify their software as necessary to make use of Phoebus and XSP. This will enable the creation of an automatically tuned data movement service, as well as the creation of appliances to act as "on-ramps" to dynamic circuit networks. Broader impact will therefore include significantly improved data transfer performance for scientific applications. Intellectual merit is found in the work's creative approach to adapting the concept of WAN acceleration to a multi-prototcol high bandwidth high delay environment.

Outcomes - OCI-1238379: STCI Net: Phoebus:

An Integrated System for End-to-end High

Performance Networking

D. Martin Swany, Ezra D. Kissel, Indiana University

 

1 Outcomes

Despite continuing advances in the link speeds of networks, data movement

remains a key problem in many scientist’s lives. In the era of Big Data, with

increasingly distributed collaborative endeavors, moving and sharing significant

amounts of data is critical. This is challenging for various reasons and

many researchers still share data by shipping physical disks. Understanding

this detriment to progress, the NSF has supported significant investments in

network capacity for educational institutions. Yet even when there is ample

infrastructure, it is not straightforward to manage high-throughput data

transfers. The goal of the Phoebus project is to produce a system that eases

this process for science users by automatically accelerating data movement.

This project supported the development of Phoebus, a protocol and

service implementation for improving end-to-end transfers to multi-gigabit

speeds. Phoebus provides a network “inlay” that augments the network

topology with an additional layer of protocol and functionality. Phoebus

leverages the ubiquitous Internet protocol implementations on end systems,

while providing an adaptor to translate to a variety of alternate protocols

over the wide area, including creation of virtual networks on the fly. Many

data-intensive applications can use Phoebus without modification and without

making any system-level changes.

This project explored, quantified and implemented various approaches to

network acceleration. We produced and made available an open source implementation

of a wide-area network accelerator system that can improve

significantly throughput for applications. We produced a body of work

studying our architecture, contributing to the understanding of wide-area

network performance issues and solutions.

We deployed Phoebus in the Internet2 network, the national research

and education backbone that connects US universities, colleges and K-12

schools. Our testing and evaluation showed dramatic performance increases,

even while using well-tuned applications that were already achieving good

performance over the standard IP network. Bill Owens, a Director at NYSERNet,

the research and education network in New York, noted “A physics

researcher at Syracuse University has been able to increase his performance

by over 10 times, reducing the time needed to transfer a dataset that is

central to his research from 40 days to less than 4!”
